text: only a few days ago they'd been enjoying
a holiday in the Sun but today victims
of flight 9268 were flown home to a cold
dark Russia a lorry transported the
bodies from some petersburg airport to a
morgue across town it was here later
that the formal process of trying to
identify the remains began this is where
the russian air bus crashed on saturday
in the sinai desert on its way back from
the seaside resort of Sharm el-sheikh
all 224 people on board were killed the
worst disaster in Russian aviation
history both black box flight recorders
have been recovered it's hoped they will
help explain why this aircraft fell from
the sky yes the purusha sturbridge
though lasers the crash site is a rather
large area it is more than 20 square
kilometres there is every indication
that destruction of the plane occurred
in the air at high altitude but if so
why Russian officials have cautioned
against jumping to conclusions about
what caused this crash they want
investigators to be given the time and
space to study all the evidence but they
also say they're not ruling anything out
in Moscow today the airline which
operated the plane Co golem I via ruled
out pilot error and mechanical failure
the company's deputy director said it
could only have been the result of some
technical physical action that made the
plane break up he didn't specify what an
Islamist militant group in Egypt said at
the weekend that it shot down the plane
but Russian and Egyptian officials are
skeptical about the claim meanwhile
that's in Petersburg airport where
flight 9268 should have landed the sea
of flowers has been growing bigger by
the minute Russians coming here to pay
their respects Russians are mourning the
dead and waiting for answers Steve
Rosenberg BBC News Moscow
